poem_title: A LETTER TO Monsieur Boileau Despreaux; Occasion'd by the VICTORY at BLENHEIM, 1704.
author: Matthew Prior
poem_alt_title: Occasion'd by the VICTORY at BLENHEIM , 1704.

lines.line_text: hir'd for Life, thy Servile Muse must sing
Successive Conquests, and a glorious King;
Must of a Man Immortal vainly boast;
And bring him Lawrels, whatsoe'er they cost:
What Turn wilt Thou employ, what Colours lay
On the Event of that Superior Day,
In which one  Subject's prosp'rous Hand
(So  did will; so  did command:)
Broke the proud Column of thy Master's Praise,
Which sixty Winters had conspir'd to raise?

stanzas.stanza_text:
hir'd for Life, thy Servile Muse must sing
Successive Conquests, and a glorious King;
Must of a Man Immortal vainly boast;
And bring him Lawrels, whatsoe'er they cost:
What Turn wilt Thou employ, what Colours lay
On the Event of that Superior Day,
In which one  Subject's prosp'rous Hand
(So  did will; so  did command:)
Broke the proud Column of thy Master's Praise,
Which sixty Winters had conspir'd to raise?

lines.line_text: From the lost Field a hundred Standards brought
Must be the Work of Chance, and Fortune's Fault:
Stars must be accus'd, which shone,
That fatal Day the mighty Work was done,
With Rays oblique upon the  Sun.
Some  envying  mis-led the Fight:
And  mistook, tho'  order'd right.

stanzas.stanza_text:
From the lost Field a hundred Standards brought
Must be the Work of Chance, and Fortune's Fault:
Stars must be accus'd, which shone,
That fatal Day the mighty Work was done,
With Rays oblique upon the  Sun.
Some  envying  mis-led the Fight:
And  mistook, tho'  order'd right.

lines.line_text: When thy young Muse invok'd the tuneful Nine,
To say how  did not pass the ,
What Work had We with ,
Places that could not be reduc'd to Rhime?
And tho' the Poet made his last Efforts,
— who could mention in Heroic — ?
But, tell me, hast thou reason to complain
Of the rough Triumphs of the last Campaign?
The  rescu'd, and the Empire sav'd,
Say, is the Majesty of Verse retriev'd?
And would it prejudice thy softer vein,
To sing the Princes,  and ?
Is it too hard in happy Verse to place
The  and  of the  and ?
Her Warriors  sends from  and ,
That  may fall by more harmonious Names.
Can'st thou not  or  bear?
Would  or  offend thy Ear?
And is there not a Sound in  Name,
Which Thou and all thy Brethren ought to claim,
Sacred to Verse, and sure of endless Fame?

What Work had We with ,
Places that could not be reduc'd to Rhime?
And tho' the Poet made his last Efforts,
— who could mention in Heroic — ?
But, tell me, hast thou reason to complain
Of the rough Triumphs of the last Campaign?
The  rescu'd, and the Empire sav'd,
Say, is the Majesty of Verse retriev'd?
And would it prejudice thy softer vein,
To sing the Princes,  and ?
Is it too hard in happy Verse to place
The  and  of the  and ?
Her Warriors  sends from  and ,
That  may fall by more harmonious Names.
Can'st thou not  or  bear?
Would  or  offend thy Ear?
And is there not a Sound in  Name,
Which Thou and all thy Brethren ought to claim,
Sacred to Verse, and sure of endless Fame?

lines.line_text: is in Meeter something harsh to read:
Place me the Valiant  in his stead:
Let the Intention make the Number good:
Let generous  speak for honest .
And tho' rough  scarce in Verse will stand,
So as to have one Rhime at his Command;
With Ease the Bard reciting  Plain,
May close the Verse, rememb'ring but the .

lines.line_text: I grant, old Friend, old Foe (for such We are
Alternate, as the Chance of Peace and War)
That we Poetic Folks, who must restrain
Our measur'd Sayings in an equal Chain,
Have Troubles utterly unknown to Those,
Who let their Fancy loose in rambling Prose.

stanzas.stanza_text:
I grant, old Friend, old Foe (for such We are
Alternate, as the Chance of Peace and War)
That we Poetic Folks, who must restrain
Our measur'd Sayings in an equal Chain,
Have Troubles utterly unknown to Those,
Who let their Fancy loose in rambling Prose.

lines.line_text: For Instance now, how hard it is for Me
To make my Matter and my Verse agree?
— sweet Numbers these.
But is it thus You  Bards compose?
With  Lays thus tag insipid Prose?
And when you should your Heroes Deeds rehearse,
Give us a Commissary's List in Verse?

stanzas.stanza_text:
For Instance now, how hard it is for Me
To make my Matter and my Verse agree?

;

;
,
;
,
— sweet Numbers these.
But is it thus You  Bards compose?
With  Lays thus tag insipid Prose?
And when you should your Heroes Deeds rehearse,
Give us a Commissary's List in Verse?

lines.line_text: Why Faith, , there's Sense in what You say:
I told You where my Difficulty lay:
So vast, so numerous were great  Spoils;
They scorn the Bounds of Verse, and mock the Muse's Toils.
To make the rough Recital aptly chime,
Or bring the Sum of  Loss to Rhime,
'Tis mighty hard: What Poet would essay
To count the Streamers of my Lord Mayor's Day?
To number all the several Dishes drest
By honest , last Coronation Feast?
Or make Arithmetic and Epic meet;
And  Thoughts in  Stile repeat?

stanzas.stanza_text:
Why Faith, , there's Sense in what You say:
I told You where my Difficulty lay:
So vast, so numerous were great  Spoils;
They scorn the Bounds of Verse, and mock the Muse's Toils.
To make the rough Recital aptly chime,
Or bring the Sum of  Loss to Rhime,
'Tis mighty hard: What Poet would essay
To count the Streamers of my Lord Mayor's Day?
To number all the several Dishes drest
By honest , last Coronation Feast?
Or make Arithmetic and Epic meet;
And  Thoughts in  Stile repeat?

lines.line_text: O Poet, had it been  Will,
That I had shar'd a Portion of thy Skill;
Had this poor Breast receiv'd the Heav'nly Beam;
Or could I hope my Verse might reach my Theam;
Yet, , yet the lab'ring Muse should strive,
Beneath the Shades of  Wreaths to live:
Should call aspiring Gods to bless her Choice;
And to their Fav'rite's Strain exalt her Voice,
Arms and a Queen to Sing; Who, Great and Good,
From peaceful  to  wond'ring Flood
Sent forth the Terror of her high Commands,
To save the Nations from invading Hands,
To prop fair Liberty's declining Cause,
And fix the jarring World with equal Laws.

stanzas.stanza_text:
O Poet, had it been  Will,
That I had shar'd a Portion of thy Skill;
Had this poor Breast receiv'd the Heav'nly Beam;
Or could I hope my Verse might reach my Theam;
Yet, , yet the lab'ring Muse should strive,
Beneath the Shades of  Wreaths to live:
Should call aspiring Gods to bless her Choice;
And to their Fav'rite's Strain exalt her Voice,
Arms and a Queen to Sing; Who, Great and Good,
From peaceful  to  wond'ring Flood
Sent forth the Terror of her high Commands,
To save the Nations from invading Hands,
To prop fair Liberty's declining Cause,
And fix the jarring World with equal Laws.

lines.line_text: The Queen should sit in  sacred Grove,
Attended by the Gods of War, and Love:
Both should with equal Zeal Her Smiles implore,
To fix Her Joys, or to extend Her Pow'r.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Queen should sit in  sacred Grove,
Attended by the Gods of War, and Love:
Both should with equal Zeal Her Smiles implore,
To fix Her Joys, or to extend Her Pow'r.

lines.line_text: Sudden, the  and  should appear;
And as great  Smiles dispel their Fear,
With active Dance should Her Observance claim;
With Vocal Shell should sound Her happy Name.
Their Master  should leave the neighb'ring Shoar,
By his strong Anchor known, and Silver Oar;
Should lay his Ensigns at his Sov'raign's Feet,
And Audience mild with humble Grace intreat.
To Her, his dear Defence, He should complain,
That whilst He blesses Her indulgent Reign;
Whilst furthest Seas are by his Fleets survey'd,
And on his happy Banks each  laid;
His Breth'ren , and , and , and
Feel the hard Burthen of oppressive War;
That  scarce retains his rightful Course
Against two Rebel Armies neighb'ring Force;
And All must weep sad Captives to the ,
Unless unchain'd and freed by  Queen.
The valiant Sov'reign calls Her Gen'ral forth;
Neither recites Her Bounty, nor His Worth:
She tells Him, He must  Fate redeem,
And by That Labour merit Her Esteem:
She bids Him wait Her to the Sacred Hall;
Shows Him Prince , and the conquer'd ;
Fixing the bloody Cross upon His Breast,
Says, He must Dye, or succour the Distress'd:
Placing the Saint an Emblem by His Side,
She tells Him, Virtue arm'd must conquer lawless Pride.
The Hero bows obedient, and retires:
The Queen's Commands exalt the Warrior's Fires.
His Steps are to the silent Woods inclin'd,
The great Design revolving in his Mind:
When to his Sight a Heav'nly Form appears:
Her Hand a Palm, her Head a Lawrel wears.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Hero bows obedient, and retires:
The Queen's Commands exalt the Warrior's Fires.
His Steps are to the silent Woods inclin'd,
The great Design revolving in his Mind:
When to his Sight a Heav'nly Form appears:
Her Hand a Palm, her Head a Lawrel wears.

lines.line_text: Me, She begins, the fairest Child of ,
Below for ever sought, and bless'd above;
Me, the bright Source of Wealth, and Power, and Fame;
(Nor need I say,  is my Name:)
Me the great Father down to Thee has sent:
He bids Me wait at Thy distinguish'd Tent,
To execute what  Wish would have:
Her Subject Thou, I only am Her Slave.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Me, She begins, the fairest Child of ,
Below for ever sought, and bless'd above;
Me, the bright Source of Wealth, and Power, and Fame;
(Nor need I say,  is my Name:)
Me the great Father down to Thee has sent:
He bids Me wait at Thy distinguish'd Tent,
To execute what  Wish would have:
Her Subject Thou, I only am Her Slave.

lines.line_text: Dare then, Thou much belov'd by smiling Fate:
For  Sake, and in Her Name, be Great:
Go forth, and be to distant Nations known,
My future Fav'rite, and My darling Son.
At  I'll manifest sustain
Thy glorious Cause; and spread my Wings again,
Conspicuous o'er Thy Helm, in  Plain.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Dare then, Thou much belov'd by smiling Fate:
For  Sake, and in Her Name, be Great:
Go forth, and be to distant Nations known,
My future Fav'rite, and My darling Son.
At  I'll manifest sustain
Thy glorious Cause; and spread my Wings again,
Conspicuous o'er Thy Helm, in  Plain.

lines.line_text: The Goddess said, nor would admit Reply;
But cut the liquid Air, and gain'd the Sky.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Goddess said, nor would admit Reply;
But cut the liquid Air, and gain'd the Sky.

lines.line_text: His high Commission is thro'  known;
And thronging Armies to His Standard run.
He marches thoughtful; and He speedy sails:
(Bless Him, ye Seas! and prosper Him, ye Gales!)
receives Him welcome to her Shores;
And  Death with lessen'd Grief deplores.
His Presence only must retrieve That Loss:
to Her must be what  was.
So when great , from these low Aboads
Recall'd, was gather'd to his Kindred-Gods;
respited by prudent Fate,
Sustain'd the Ball, nor droop'd beneath the Weight.

stanzas.stanza_text:
His high Commission is thro'  known;
And thronging Armies to His Standard run.
He marches thoughtful; and He speedy sails:
(Bless Him, ye Seas! and prosper Him, ye Gales!)
receives Him welcome to her Shores;
And  Death with lessen'd Grief deplores.
His Presence only must retrieve That Loss:
to Her must be what  was.
So when great , from these low Aboads
Recall'd, was gather'd to his Kindred-Gods;
respited by prudent Fate,
Sustain'd the Ball, nor droop'd beneath the Weight.

lines.line_text: Secret and Swift behold the Chief advance;
Sees half the Empire join'd, and Friend to :
The  General dooms the Fight: His Sword
Dreadful He draws: The Captains wait the Word.
and St. , the charging Hero cries:
Shrill Echo from the neighb'ring Wood replies
and St. . — At That auspicious Sign
The Standards move; the adverse Armies join.
Of Eight great Hours, Time measures out the Sands;
And  Fate in doubtful Balance stands:
The Ninth,  comes: — o'er  Head
Confess'd She sits: the Hostile Troops recede: —
Triumphs the , from her Promise freed.

Secret and Swift behold the Chief advance;
Sees half the Empire join'd, and Friend to :
The  General dooms the Fight: His Sword
Dreadful He draws: The Captains wait the Word.
and St. , the charging Hero cries:
Shrill Echo from the neighb'ring Wood replies
and St. . — At That auspicious Sign
The Standards move; the adverse Armies join.
Of Eight great Hours, Time measures out the Sands;
And  Fate in doubtful Balance stands:
The Ninth,  comes: — o'er  Head
Confess'd She sits: the Hostile Troops recede: —
Triumphs the , from her Promise freed.

lines.line_text: The Eagle, by the  Lion's Might
Unchain'd and Free, directs her upward Flight:
Nor did She e'er with stronger Pinions soar
From  Banks, than now from  Shoar.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Eagle, by the  Lion's Might
Unchain'd and Free, directs her upward Flight:
Nor did She e'er with stronger Pinions soar
From  Banks, than now from  Shoar.

lines.line_text: Fir'd with the Thoughts which these Ideas raise,
And great Ambition of my Country's Praise;
The  Muse should like the  rise;
Scornful of Earth and Clouds, should reach the Skies,
With Wonder (tho' with Envy still) pursu'd by human Eyes.
But We must change the Style. — Just now I said,
I ne'er was Master of the tuneful Trade.
Or the small Genius which my Youth could boast,
In Prose and Business lies extinct and lost:
Bless'd, if I may some younger Muse excite;
Point out the Game, and animate the Flight:
That from  to   may know,
As We have Conqu'rors, We have Poets too;
And either Laurel does in  grow:
That, tho' amongst our selves, with too much Heat,
We sometimes wrangle, when We should debate;
(A consequential Ill which Freedom draws;
A bad Effect, but from a Noble Cause:)
We can with universal Zeal advance,
To curb the faithless Arrogance of .
Nor ever shall  Sons refuse
To answer to thy Master, or thy Muse;
Nor want just Subject for victorious Strains,
While  Arm Eternal Laurel gains;
And where old  sung, a new  reigns.
